collection.description: Donald and Vera Ward were married graduates of Northwestern University with influential careers in midcentury Chicago-based radio, television, theatre, and the ministry. Donald’s successful and varied career spanned radio and television, Christian ministry, and higher education. Although her husband left the world of performing arts to become a Congregational pastor in 1959, the stage and screen remained Vera’s life’s work: she appeared in several acclaimed plays and television advertising campaigns and founded multiple theatre programs through the churches at which her husband ministered.

description: These films are from Donald Ward’s travels as a young man through Europe with his grandmother, Emma Ward. Part One and Part Two were taken in the Rhineland. Part Two also has shots of the Nazi flag hanging from various shops and buildings. These films are part of the greater Donald and Vera Ward collection. Donald and Vera Ward were married graduates of Northwestern University with influential careers in midcentury Chicago-based radio, television, theatre, and the ministry. Donald’s successful and varied career spanned radio and television, Christian ministry, and higher education. Although her husband left the world of performing arts to become a Congregational pastor in 1959, the stage and screen remained Vera’s life’s work: she appeared in several acclaimed plays and television advertising campaigns and founded multiple theatre programs through the churches at which her husband ministered.
title: Travels in Europe, Germany

series: Donald (1919-1994) and Vera (1922-2014) Ward Papers--Don and Vera Ward Oversized Artifacts and Media, 1935-2004
description: Don Ward guest hosts “The Benny Rubin Show” for the sick Benny Rubin. Vera Ward guest stars in the program. The program features the Wards performing various comedy sketches and Don’s interview with Joey, a young man with cerebral palsy who had won a prize for songwriting. Throughout the program, Rex Maupin and his orchestra perform “I Married an Angel,” “Riverboat Shuffle,” “I’ll String Along with You” and “Night Magic.” Donald and Vera Ward were married graduates of Northwestern University with influential careers in midcentury Chicago-based radio, television, theatre, and the ministry. Donald’s successful and varied career spanned radio and television, Christian ministry, and higher education. Although her husband left the world of performing arts to become a Congregational pastor in 1959, the stage and screen remained Vera’s life’s work: she appeared in several acclaimed plays and television advertising campaigns and founded multiple theatre programs through the churches at which her husband ministered.
title: Benny Rubin Show

description: This film is a compilation of daily bible readings featuring Donald and Vera Ward reading various Bible passages including the 23rd, 46th, and 100th psalm. In addition, there are readings from the book of Isaiah, chapters 9, 11, and 53, the gospel of Matthew, chapters 2, 5, 6, 7, 18, 22, and 25, the gospel of Mark, chapter 12, the gospel of Luke, chapters 7, 10, 14, and 15, the first letter of Paul to the Corinthians, chapter 13, the first letter of Paul to the Romans, chapters 8 and 12, the gospel of John, chapters 1, 3, and 14, and the first letter of John, chapter 4. Donald and Vera Ward were married graduates of Northwestern University with influential careers in midcentury Chicago-based radio, television, theatre, and the ministry. Donald’s successful and varied career spanned radio and television, Christian ministry, and higher education. Although her husband left the world of performing arts to become a Congregational pastor in 1959, the stage and screen remained Vera’s life’s work: she appeared in several acclaimed plays and television advertising campaigns and founded multiple theatre programs through the churches at which her husband ministered.
title: Bible Readings, 1955

description: Don Ward guest hosts “The Benny Rubin Show” for the sick Benny Rubin. The program features jokes by Ward, an interview with singer Dolly Houston, and music performances and recordings. Houston performs with the orchestra and sings "Lonesome Gal." Music recordings include "Laura," "That's my girl" sung by Nat King Cole, and a recording of "And then I prayed," written by Maurice Murray. Donald and Vera Ward were married graduates of Northwestern University with influential careers in midcentury Chicago-based radio, television, theatre, and the ministry. Donald’s successful and varied career spanned radio and television, Christian ministry, and higher education. Although her husband left the world of performing arts to become a Congregational pastor in 1959, the stage and screen remained Vera’s life’s work: she appeared in several acclaimed plays and television advertising campaigns and founded multiple theatre programs through the churches at which her husband ministered.

series: Donald (1919-1994) and Vera (1922-2014) Ward Papers--Don and Vera Ward Oversized Artifacts and Media, 1935-2004
description: This film features scenes from Vera Bantz Ward's trip to New York City. There are numerous shots of billboards for various Broadway plays like Cactus Flower, Hello Dolly, Fiddler on the Roof, Funny Girl, The Apple Tree, Dinner at Eight, and The Bible. There are also street scenes of New York like food vendors, hotels, skyscrapers, and pedestrians on the street. These films are part of the greater Donald and Vera Ward collection. Donald and Vera Ward were married graduates of Northwestern University with influential careers in midcentury Chicago-based radio, television, theatre, and the ministry. Donald’s successful and varied career spanned radio and television, Christian ministry, and higher education. Although her husband left the world of performing arts to become a Congregational pastor in 1959, the stage and screen remained Vera’s life’s work: she appeared in several acclaimed plays and television advertising campaigns and founded multiple theatre programs through the churches at which her husband ministered.
title: New York Scenes

series: Donald (1919-1994) and Vera (1922-2014) Ward Papers--Don and Vera Ward Oversized Artifacts and Media, 1935-2004
description: These films are from Donald Ward’s travels as a young man through Europe with his grandmother, Emma Ward. This particular film is mostly of their travels through Italy. There are scenes of people feeding pigeons in St. Mark's Square and a gondola ride in Venice. There are also scenes from the Vatican, including St. Peter's Square and St. Peter's Basilica. In addition, there are images of the Trevi fountain and the Colosseum in Rome, Italy. Finally, there are scenes taken at the Leaning Tower of Pisa, along the Italian coast, and on a boat. These films are part of the greater Donald and Vera Ward collection. Donald and Vera Ward were married graduates of Northwestern University with influential careers in midcentury Chicago-based radio, television, theatre, and the ministry. Donald’s successful and varied career spanned radio and television, Christian ministry, and higher education. Although her husband left the world of performing arts to become a Congregational pastor in 1959, the stage and screen remained Vera’s life’s work: she appeared in several acclaimed plays and television advertising campaigns and founded multiple theatre programs through the churches at which her husband ministered.
title: Travels in Europe, Italy

description: This film is a compilation of daily bible readings featuring Donald and Vera Ward reading various Bible passages including the 19th, 27th, 46th, 103rd, 121st, and 145th psalm. In addition, there are readings from the book of Hebrews, chapter 11, the book of Isaiah, chapters 40 and 55, the book of Proverbs, chapter 3, the book of Deuteronomy, chapter 5, the gospel of Matthew, chapter 6, the gospel of Luke, chapters 1, 2, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 15, the first letter of Paul to the Corinthians, chapter 13, the first letter of Paul to the Romans, chapters 8 and 12, the letter of Paul to the Philippians, chapter 4, the gospel of John, chapters 1, 3, 4, 15, and 17, and the Acts of the Apostles, chapter 17. Donald and Vera Ward were married graduates of Northwestern University with influential careers in midcentury Chicago-based radio, television, theatre, and the ministry. Donald’s successful and varied career spanned radio and television, Christian ministry, and higher education. Although her husband left the world of performing arts to become a Congregational pastor in 1959, the stage and screen remained Vera’s life’s work: she appeared in several acclaimed plays and television advertising campaigns and founded multiple theatre programs through the churches at which her husband ministered.

series: Donald (1919-1994) and Vera (1922-2014) Ward Papers--Don and Vera Ward Oversized Artifacts and Media, 1935-2004
description: Chalk It Up is a televised panel game hosted by Donald Ward. At the time of this filming, Donald Ward was a minister at Congregational church in the Denver area. The members of the panel were clergymen of other churches in the Denver area. Donald would describe objects from the Bible to the panelists, and they had to draw the object based on Donald's descriptions. After the panelists had completed the drawing, they would discuss the significance of the object in terms of scripture and Christian life. Donald and Vera Ward were married graduates of Northwestern University with influential careers in midcentury Chicago-based radio, television, theatre, and the ministry. Donald’s successful and varied career spanned radio and television, Christian ministry, and higher education. Although her husband left the world of performing arts to become a Congregational pastor in 1959, the stage and screen remained Vera’s life’s work: she appeared in several acclaimed plays and television advertising campaigns and founded multiple theatre programs through the churches at which her husband ministered.
title: Chalk It Up, 1962

series: Donald (1919-1994) and Vera (1922-2014) Ward Papers--Don and Vera Ward Oversized Artifacts and Media, 1935-2004
description: Don Ward guest stars on “The Benny Rubin Show.” This program features Rubin’s interview with Eunice Gray, author of the book “Steffi.” Don Ward and his puppets perform a comedy sketch and song that were part of his ongoing puppetry show. Ralph Flanagan and his orchestra perform “What Is This Thing Called Love” and “Hearts and Flowers.” Donald and Vera Ward were married graduates of Northwestern University with influential careers in midcentury Chicago-based radio, television, theatre, and the ministry. Donald’s successful and varied career spanned radio and television, Christian ministry, and higher education. Although her husband left the world of performing arts to become a Congregational pastor in 1959, the stage and screen remained Vera’s life’s work: she appeared in several acclaimed plays and television advertising campaigns and founded multiple theatre programs through the churches at which her husband ministered.
title: Benny Rubin Show: Interview and Puppets
